ring theory

Let AAA be a commutative ring, SSS a multiplicatively closed subset of AAA, A→A[S−1]A \to A\br{S^{-1}}A→A[S−1] the localization.

  1. Which elements of AAA map to zero in A[S−1]A\br{S^{-1}}A[S−1]?
  2. Let p\mathfrak{p}p be a prime ideal in AAA. Show that the ideal generated by the image of p\mathfrak{p}p in A[S−1]A\br{S^{-1}}A[S−1] is prime if and only if the intersection of p\mathfrak{p}p with SSS is empty.
Solution.

  1. Suppose aaa maps to 000 in A[S−1]A\br{S^{-1}}A[S−1]; that is, a1=0\frac{a}{1} = 01a​=0. By definition, there exists s∈Ss \in Ss∈S so that as=0as = 0as=0 in AAA. Conversely, suppose a∈Aa \in Aa∈A is annihilated by SSS, i.e., as=0as = 0as=0 for some s∈Ss \in Ss∈S. Then in A[S−1]A\br{S^{-1}}A[S−1], we have

    a1=ass=0,\frac{a}{1} = \frac{as}{s} = 0,1a​=sas​=0,

    so the elements in AAA which map to zero in the localization are precisely the elements annihilated by SSS.

  2. "  ⟹  \implies⟹"

    Assume the ideal I=S−1pI = S^{-1}\mathfrak{p}I=S−1p is prime. If there exists s∈p∩Ss \in \mathfrak{p} \cap Ss∈p∩S, then III is all of A[S−1]A\br{S^{-1}}A[S−1], but this means III is not prime. Thus, p∩S=∅\mathfrak{p} \cap S = \emptysetp∩S=∅.

    "  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

    Suppose p∩S=∅\mathfrak{p} \cap S = \emptysetp∩S=∅, and assume as⋅bt∈I\frac{a}{s} \cdot \frac{b}{t} \in Isa​⋅tb​∈I, where III is as above. Then abst=pr\frac{ab}{st} = \frac{p}{r}stab​=rp​ for some p∈pp \in \mathfrak{p}p∈p. Thus, rab=pst∈prab = pst \in \mathfrak{p}rab=pst∈p, and by assumption, r∉pr \notin \mathfrak{p}r∈/p, so because p\mathfrak{p}p is prime, we have ab∈pab \in \mathfrak{p}ab∈p. Thus, aaa or bbb is in p\mathfrak{p}p, which implies as\frac{a}{s}sa​ or bt\frac{b}{t}tb​ is in III, so III is prime.
